Hello, World

The obligatory first post

January 2, 2023

Yes, yet another tech blog. I'll do my best to keep this about technology in general, software engineering, etc. but who knows what I'll rant about. For starters, let's see how this simple blog was made!

Javascript everywhere

I admit it - I come from a Javascript framework focused background. When I was really first starting off AngularJs was still en vogue with React only starting to gain traction. As such, the way I think about web UIs is through Components. The component model is an excellent abstraction and checks all the boxes for composability and reusability. These libraries have nurtured a whole sector of software engineering in "frontend development" by allowing devs to seemlessly weave together their HTML, CSS, and Javascript logic (or Typescript if you're lucky). The result is we have a generous amount of extremely complex web applications. However, as been stressed many times, frameworks are not the silver bullet that our industry makes us think they are.

I'm using this blog as the prime example - there is no need for an entire framework. Just like the good 'ol days, it's a mostly static website that's nicely separated by individual pages that can all be navigated to. By shedding all the Javascript

While I resist to use a framework, I concede that the Component model is powerfull. As mentioned earlier, there is a lot to gain and components could help streamline building and (more importantly) maintaining the blog. How awesome would it be that instead of having to redeclare all the HTML boilerplate for each page, we could just use a resuable Tag or Component?

Introducing the <z> tag

It turns out we can get all the benefits of components without having to bring in frameworks - we just have to build it! 


  // index.html
  <z component="blog">
    <div>blah blah blah</div>
  </z>

I created a new synthetic HTML tag which, with a little help from Javascript, can define some custom behavior. In this case, we say that we want to render the blog component (similar to how you would with any other native element tag).

Now say our layout component looked as follows:


  // blog.html
  <article>
    <h3>A Blog Title</h3>
    <z yield></z>
  </article>

This defines a simple Blog component that can be reused throught our site. For our exmaple, this layout markup will replace the <z> element. Also pay notice to that yield attribute. This is something inspired by EmberJs where the child elements of the consuming component will be transfused into the yield statement. This is best explained though examples, so our end result is: 


  // dist/index.html
  <article>
    <h3>A Blog Title</h3>
    <div>blah blah blah</div>
  </article>

Pretty cool!

I've extend this further to allow very basic data passing (props) to help make components more customizable and reusable. With some small changes we can do even cooler things: 


  // index.html
  <z component="blog" blog-title="React who?">
    <div>blah blah blah</div>
  </z>

  // blog.html
  <article>
    <h3><% blog-title %>/h3>
    <z yield></z>
  </article>

  // dist/index.html
  <article>
    <h3>React who?</h3>
    <div>blah blah blah</div>
  </article>
